contentrichtext.text: {{Update|date=June 2011}} '''Pei-Yuan Wei''' ({{zh|c=魏培源|p=Wèi Péiyuán}}) is the creator of [[ViolaWWW]], the first popular graphical [[web browser]]. Pei-Yuan Wei was born in [[Taiwan]].<ref>[http://www.xcf.berkeley.edu/~wei/ Pei's Home Page]</ref> He graduated from [[Berkeley High School (California)|Berkeley High School]] {{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} in 1986 and received his higher education at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} ==Controversy== Pei-Yuan Wei was at the center of a controversy over patents relating to embedded objects in a web browser,<ref name="ZDNet2003_10_03">{{cite web|url=http://news.zdnet.com/2100-3513-5088349.html|title=Eolas files motion to enjoin IE|publisher=[[Ziff-Davis]]|date=2003-10-03|author=Paul Festa}}</ref><ref name="Times2005_03_04">{{cite web|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/technology/article418430.ece?token=null&offset=12|title=Future of the web to go on trial|author= Rhys Blakely|publisher=''[[The Times]]'' ([[United Kingdom]])|date=2005-03-04}}</ref> which revolves around whether his browser, ViolaWWW, had the capability to launch embedded objects, prior to the date a patent was filed by [[Michael David Doyle]] of [[Eolas]], and the [[University of California]].<ref name="ZDNet2003_10_03"/> If it did, it would constitute [[prior art]], which may invalidate the patent issued to [[Eolas]].<ref name="ZDNet2003_10_03"/><ref name="Times2005_03_04"/> If it did not, in addition to major financial penalties against such companies as Microsoft, the way the World Wide Web and the way browsers that surf it work may be forced to change.<ref name="ZDNet2003_10_03"/> Eolas' claim was eventually found invalid by a Texas court.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/02/interactive-web-patent/?utm_source=Contextly&utm_medium=RelatedLinks&utm_campaign=MoreRecently |title= Texas Jury Strikes Down Patent Troll’s Claim to Own the Interactive Web |publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |author=Joe Mullin |date= February 9, 2012 |accessdate=July 24, 2012 }}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *
